May 5, 1991: Fiction
THE SEERESS OF KELL, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $20.) The fifth
volume in the "Malloreon" fantasy saga.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man
and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve
their romantic problems.
ASPEN GOLD, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A woman returns to her
native Colorado to face a choice: fame in Hollywood or love with an old flame.
THE NOVEL, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $23.) Life as lived by
writers, critics and book editors in the Pennsylvania Dutch country and in
Manhattan.
DAMAGE, by Josephine Hart. (Knopf, $18.) A British gentleman is mesmerized
when he meets the woman his son plans to marry.
THE DRUID OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) A
new volume in a series about the fantasy land of Shannara.
THE SEVENTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $21.95.) The
temptations experienced by an insurance company investigator when she probes
the murder of a millionaire.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE EAGLE HAS FLOWN, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A
German general plots a daring rescue attempt during World War II.
EYES OF PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $19.95.) Lieut. Lucas Davenport on
the trail of a serial killer in the Twin Cities.
HOW TO MAKE AN AMERICAN QUILT, by Whitney Otto. (Villard, $18.) The
reminiscences of eight women, members of a quilting circle in a small California
town.
THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on
horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age.
COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds
hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan.
"H" IS FOR HOMICIDE, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $17.95.) The private eye Kinsey
Non-Fiction
NANCY REAGAN, by Kitty Kelley. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) An unauthorized
biography of the former First Lady.
YOU'LL NEVER EAT LUNCH IN THIS TOWN AGAIN, by Julia Phillips. (Random
House, $22.) Life in Hollywood as experienced by an Academy Award-winning
producer.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
MOVING PICTURES, by Ali MacGraw. (Bantam, $20.) The film star of the 1970's
looks back on her checkered career.
LIFE IS TOO SHORT, by Mickey Rooney. (Villard, $22.50.) The autobiography of
the movie star.
A HISTORY OF THE ARAB PEOPLES, by Albert Hourani. (Belknap/Harvard
University, $24.95.) A comprehensive account from Mohammed's time to the
present; the work of an Oxford scholar.
THERE ARE NO CHILDREN HERE, by Alex Kotlowitz. (Talese/Doubleday,
$21.95.) The story of two brothers growing up on Chicago's mean streets.
MY FAVORITE SUMMER 1956, by Mickey Mantle and Phil Pepe. (Doubleday,
$18.95.) The recollections of the New York Yankees' star center fielder and home-
run hitter.
I HAD A HAMMER, by Henry Aaron with Lonnie Wheeler. (HarperCollins, $21.95.)
From the Negro leagues to the National League's most valuable player: the
record-breaking baseball player's life.
IN OUR DEFENSE, by Ellen Alderman and Caroline Kennedy. (Morrow, $22.95.)
How the Bill of Rights affects Americans' lives today.
SLEEPWALKING THROUGH HISTORY, by Haynes Johnson. (Norton, $24.95.) A
social history of America during the Reagan era.
RYAN WHITE: My Own Story, by Ryan White and Ann Marie Cunningham. (Dial,
$16.95.) The experiences of an Indiana youth who was diagnosed as having AIDS
at age 13 and died five years later.
YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The
different languages men and women speak.
THE PROMISED LAND, by Nicholas Lemann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The 20th-century
migration of blacks from the rural South to the urban North.
